review.title: A Time-Vertex Signal Processing Framework
review.abstract: An emerging way to deal with high-dimensional non-euclidean data is to assume that the underlying structure can be captured by a graph. Recently, ideas have begun to emerge related to the analysis of time-varying graph signals. This work aims to elevate the notion of joint harmonic analysis to a full-fledged framework denoted as Time-Vertex Signal Processing, that links together the time-domain signal processing techniques with the new tools of graph signal processing. This entails three main contributions: (a) We provide a formal motivation for harmonic time-vertex analysis as an analysis tool for the state evolution of simple Partial Differential Equations on graphs. (b) We improve the accuracy of joint filtering operators by up-to two orders of magnitude. (c) Using our joint filters, we construct time-vertex dictionaries analyzing the different scales and the local time-frequency content of a signal. The utility of our tools is illustrated in numerous applications and datasets, such as dynamic mesh denoising and classification, still-video inpainting, and source localization in seismic events. Our results suggest that joint analysis of time-vertex signals can bring benefits to regression and learning.

sections.heading: B. Time-vertex calculus and variation
sections.text: In the following, we will briefly introduce the most important time matrix, which will help us (a) to perform calculations over finite, discrete time and space, and (b) to characterize the properties of the signals, such as smoothness, while taking into account the intrinsic structure of the data domain in time. sections.heading: III. DYNAMICS OVER GRAPHS
sections.text: This section further motivates the JFT by showing that it can be used to characterize two linear PDEs that develop above the graph through nuclei defined in the common frequency domain, and also to provide insights into standard non-linear PDEs used in epidemic modeling. Our interest in PDEs analysis is related to their ability to encode information about the structure of the underlying domain, whether continuous or discrete [38], [39] In addition, PDEs are not only simple but powerful models of many phenomena observed in reality, but also a motivation for the Fourier transformation [40], [41].5

sections.heading: A. Linear dynamics on graphs
sections.text: We are interested in linear PDEs, the solution of which can be expressed in each time step as a linear operator applied to the initial condition. In particular, we consider heat diffusion and the wave equations defined in the discrete setting. We call x1 the initial condition of the PDEs, or equivalent in the common spectral domain Z (, "k) = x ² 1 (") U ² T (k, 1). The parameter s represents the thermal diffusivity and is interpreted as a scale parameter for multi-scale dynamic wave analysis. [15] and the graph space theory [42]. It is well understood that xt = (I − sLG) t − 1x1. (16) When evaluating both the GFT and the DFT, one finds that the solution also has a different structure in the fusion.

sections.heading: B. Complex dynamics over networks: the illustrative example of epidemic models
sections.text: To illustrate this, we will show how the JFT can be used to characterize the development of a non-linear, discrete, and non-deterministic model for the spread of an infectious disease. We have simulated the epidemics spreading across N = 695 cities in Europe using two different models: the Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered (SEIR) model and the SEIRS model, in which the immunity of recovered individuals is only temporary; the models are parameterized by the likelihood of infection, the latent and immunity periods, and the population per city.

sections.heading: IV. FAST FILTERING OF TIME-VERTEX SIGNALS
sections.text: After remembering the definition of common filters, we will next introduce a novel algorithm for fast filtering of large graphs. Experiments show that our algorithm achieves a much better approximation of filter objectives than the state of the art, without being limited to a specific class of separable reactions.

sections.heading: A. Joint time-vertex filters
sections.text: A common filter h (LG, LT) is a function defined in the common two-dimensional spectral range h: R + · R 7 → C and evaluated on the basis of graph eigenvalues λ and angular frequencies ω. Similar to both the classic and the graph case, the generalized filter operator is applied by means of the convolution theorem, i.e., pointwise multiplication in the spectral domain. The output of a common filter (LG, LT) x = UJ h-filter h-filter h-filter U х J x-filter, (20) where h-filter is a diagonal NT-matrix defined ash-filter-filter-time-filter-filter-time-filter-matrix-filter-filter-time-filter-filter-matrix-filter-time-filter-filter-filter-time-filter-filter.

sections.heading: B. Fast joint filtering
sections.text: Due to the high complexity of self-decomposition, graph filters are almost always implemented using fast 2D polynomials (43) and rationalizations (31). In the context of time-vertex analysis, the importance of fast common filtering is emphasized by increasing the dimensions of the problem. However, below, we will improve the state of the art by improving filtering approximation at a similar point (up to logarithmic factors). The Fast Fourier Chebyshev (FFC) algorithm is the basic idea of our algorithms to exploit the small complexity of FFT and perform graphs in the time-frequency domain.

sections.heading: V. TIME-VERTEX DICTIONARIES AND FRAMES
sections.text: So far, we have looked at the time-vertex signals through the lenses of the canonical and common Fourier base. However, in some cases it is beneficial to consider alternative representations as well. For example, in the classical case, the waveform and the short time that Fourier transforms may allow a time and frequency analysis of the signal. The purpose of this section is to show how to define analog representations for time-vertex signals, which can be used, for example, to generate features that are given to a classifier as input (see Section VI-C) or to regulate an optimization problem, such as (41) in Section VI-C.8. Classically, the atoms of representations are constructed by applying a transform (e.g. scaling or modulation) to a parent function and shifting the resulting functions.

sections.heading: A. Joint time-vertex localization
sections.text: The ability to localize a kernel over a certain time and vertex is a key component of our dictionary construction. In the following, we derive such a common localization operator as a generalization of the graph localization operator [12], [36], [44] which centers a core h (LG) on the vertex vmT Gm h = h (LG) δm = N ∑ '= 1 h (λ') u (m) u. (26) It turns out that the common time-vertex localization operator has the advantages of both graph localization and traditional translation operators.

This form of transformation can be considered modulable. Nevertheless, we note that it is not a multiplication by a eigenvector in [36], [47]. Our construction is more akin to [48, Section 3].

sections.heading: C. Joint time-vertex frames
sections.text: To make the proposed dictionaries and associated signal representations usable in practice, we next give answers to three key questions: (a) How can we efficiently calculate the representations (i.e., perform analysis and synthesis)? (b) How can we guarantee that the associated transformations are conditioned to be successfully inverted? (c) How can we efficiently invert them and restore the original signal? (c) The second point is particularly important because a well-conditioned transformation enables more robust representations, for example, when the dictionary is used to solve a synthesis or analysis regression problem with a sparse regression problem. (c) Efficient analysis and synthesis is particularly important because a well-conditioned transformation enables more robust representations, e.g. when the dictionary is used to solve a synthesis or analysis regression problem with a sparse regression problem.

sections.heading: VI. EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: The suitability of the time-vertex framework for various types of problems is illustrated by a variety of data sets: (a) dynamic meshes representing a walking dog and a dancing man; (b) the Caltrans Performance Measurement System (PeMS) traffic dataset representing a high-resolution daily vehicle flow of 10 consecutive days on Sacramento highways measured every 5 minutes; (c) simulated SEIR or SEIRS-like epidemics across Europe; (d) the time-lapse video of Kuala Lumpur city center (KLCC); and (e) seismic waves recorded from geographically distributed seismic stations connected to the GeoNet network in New Zealand. Results suggest that a common analysis of time-vertex signals can bring benefits in signal denoising and recovery, learning and source localization problems.

sections.heading: A. Compactness of representation
sections.text: A key motivation behind the common harmonic analysis is the ability to encode time-dependent graphical signal developments in a compact way. Therefore, our first step will be to investigate the energy compression of the JFT transformation in four datasets: two meshes representing a dancer (N = 1502 points in R3 and T = 570 timestamps) and a dog walking (N = 2502 points in R3 and T = 52 timestamps), the PeMS traffic flow dataset (N = 710 stations measuring traffic over T = 2880 intervals of 5 minutes each), and the number of infected persons in a SEIRS epidemic (see section III-B for description). Transformations with good energy compression are desirable because they can well summarize and use the data to construct efficient regulators for regression problems. To measure energy compactness, we compress the DFT, GFT, and JFT effectiveness for each data set by the X coefficient of the magnitude X.

sections.heading: B. Regression problems with joint variation priors
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

sections.heading: C. Overcomplete representations
sections.text: Finally, we examine the utility of the STVFT and STVWT, respectively, as a feature we have used for dynamic clustering and as a dictionary to reveal the wave structure and epicenter of a seismic event. We consider the motion classification of a dynamic mesh representing the dancer as an additional, economical noise with a density of 0.1 with normally distributed entries and SNR of − 20 dB and − 10 dB. Our goal is to determine the phase of the dance (moving arms, stretching legs and bending body) on each frame by performing spectral clustering on some representations of the winding signal. To obtain the ground truth, we manually mark each frame and verify that the noiseless signal (i.e., the actual trajectory of the points in each window) was used to define the characteristics, a classification accuracy of 0.926.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This paper introduces a Time-Vertex Signal Processing Framework that facilitates the analysis of graph-structured data that also evolves over time. We motivate our framework by using the idea of partial differential equation in diagrams. We introduce common operators, such as time-vertex localization, and present a novel approach to greatly improve the accuracy of fast common filtering. We also show how to build time-vertex dictionaries that provide conditions for efficient invertex and construction examples. Our experimental results on a variety of data sets suggest that the proposed tools can bring significant benefits to various signal processing and learning tasks with time series on diagrams.

In the field of graph signal processing (GSP), the introduction of the graph Fourier transform (GFT) has enabled us to perform harmonic analysis taking into account the structure of the data, and has lead to improvements for tasks such as clustering [10], low-rank extraction [11], spectral estimation [12], [13], non-stationary analysis [14], [15] and semi-supervised learning [16], [17].

The idea of analyzing the behavior of graph filters with time-varying signals first appeared in [28], showing that graph filters could be analyzed by applying jointly a GFT and a Ztransform and as such they possess a joint frequency response.

Since then, we have seen a number of works dealing with time-varying signals on graphs: Authors in [29] propose a method that relies on graph wavelet theory and product graphs to visualize time-varying data defined on the vertices of a graph in order to identify spatial and/or temporal variations.

metadata.abstractText: An emerging way to deal with highdimensional non-euclidean data is to assume that the underlying structure can be captured by a graph. Recently, ideas have begun to emerge related to the analysis of time-varying graph signals. This work aims to elevate the notion of joint harmonic analysis to a full-fledged framework denoted as Time-Vertex Signal Processing, that links together the time-domain signal processing techniques with the new tools of graph signal processing. This entails three main contributions: (a) We provide a formal motivation for harmonic time-vertex analysis as an analysis tool for the state evolution of simple Partial Differential Equations on graphs. (b) We improve the accuracy of joint filtering operators by up-to two orders of magnitude. (c) Using our joint filters, we construct time-vertex dictionaries analyzing the different scales and the local time-frequency content of a signal. The utility of our tools is illustrated in numerous applications and datasets, such as dynamic mesh denoising and classification, still-video inpainting, and source localization in seismic events. Our results suggest that joint analysis of time-vertex signals can bring benefits to regression and learning.
